verses.text: Blessed is the nation whose God is the LORD, the people he chose for his inheritance.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 33 There are twenty-two verses in the psalm, the same as the number of letters in the Hebrew alphabet, but the psalm is not an acrostic (see Introduction to Hebrew Poetry).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:12
rsbNotes.text: 33:12 the people whom he has chosen. God is the One who initiated the relationship with Israel, the nation He chose (Deut. 7:7–11).

verses.text: From heaven the LORD looks down and sees all mankind;
from his dwelling place he watches all who live on earth-

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:13
rsbNotes.text: 33:13 heaven. See “Heaven” at Rev. 21:1.

verses.text: he who forms the hearts of all, who considers everything they do.
No king is saved by the size of his army; no warrior escapes by his great strength.
A horse is a vain hope for deliverance; despite all its great strength it cannot save.
But the eyes of the LORD are on those who fear him, on those whose hope is in his unfailing love,
to deliver them from death and keep them alive in famine.
We wait in hope for the LORD; he is our help and our shield.
In him our hearts rejoice, for we trust in his holy name.
May your unfailing love rest upon us, O LORD, even as we put our hope in you.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 33:15
rsbNotes.text: 33:15 God not only sees all, He forms the hearts of all.
